item.title: Referendum to Let Bolivian President Seek a Fourth Term Appears Headed for Defeat
item.description: The popularity of Evo Morales, a left-wing leader whose years in office have coincided with wider prosperity, had slipped with the referendum’s approach.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY and MONICA MACHICAO
item.media:description: President Evo Morales of Bolivia at a ceremony last week for new housing built by the government. A referendum on Sunday is to determine whether to change term limits and allow Mr. Morales, now in his third term, to run again.

item.title: Iran’s Thwarted Reformers Set Careful Goals for Coming Vote
item.description: The agenda of the reformers, once a sweeping manifesto for change in the Islamic republic, has been reduced to simply calling for a high turnout in Friday’s balloting.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A rally for reform candidates in Tehran over the weekend. As the reformists try to stage a comeback, their political agenda has been narrowed to calling for a high turnout in the coming vote.

item.title: India Sends Troops to Disrupt Protest Parching Delhi
item.description: The unrest in Haryana State by the Jats, a rural caste, has left 10 dead, forced factories to close and severely restricted water supplies.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Newly Elected Central African Republic Leader Faces Hard Realities
item.description: Faustin Archange Touadéra, a former prime minister, was declared the winner of the presidential election in the Central African Republic, which emerged from a civil war with a devastated economy.
item.dc:creator: MARGAUX BENN
item.media:description: Faustin Archange Touadéra after voting on Feb. 14 in the Central African Republic election. He won the presidency.

item.title: U.S. Scrambles to Contain Growing ISIS Threat in Libya
item.description: As U.S. intelligence agencies say the number of Islamic State fighters in Iraq and Syria has dropped, the group’s ranks in Libya have roughly doubled.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senegalese commandos during a recent United States-led training exercise in Senegal.

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: Reporting on Life, Death and Corruption in Southeast Asia
item.description: Thomas Fuller, a New York Times correspondent who is leaving the region after a decade, says one theme there keeps recurring: impunity.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Agnes Dherbeys for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thai soldiers facing rival groups of antigovernment and pro-government protesters in Bangkok in April 2010.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: When Peacekeepers Come Home
item.description: Struggling poor countries rent troops to the U.N. who can return as an influence on politics.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN D. CAVERLEY and JESSE DILLON SAVAGE

item.title: Truce Unravels as Fighting Picks Up in Ukraine
item.description: A resumption of hostilities suggests that Russia, which supports the rebels, is willing to sustain the conflict there as well as in Syria.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Mikhailo M. Prokopiv, commander of Ukrainian Army forces in Maryinka, Ukraine, looked toward territory held by Russia-backed rebels on Sunday.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: What Passes for Sedition in India
item.description: The message is clear: Violence in the name of ultra-nationalism is acceptable. Not even the courts are safe spaces.
item.dc:creator: NILANJANA S. ROY

item.title: Political Memo: London Mayor Joins Chorus Demanding Exit From E.U.
item.description: The announcement by Mayor Boris Johnson, one of the Conservative Party’s most popular figures, is a new challenge for Prime Minister David Cameron.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: U.S. and Russia Near Deal on Partial Truce in Syria, Kerry Says
item.description: The secretary of state said the “cessation of hostilities” would go into effect in days, but did not give a specific deadline.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Wales Journal: Welsh Town Leads a British Revolt Against the Tax System and Corporations
item.description: Crickhowell, population 2,063, has become famous for being one of Britain’s last holdouts against the encroachment of big retail chains.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steven Askew, a baker, said he and his wife each worked 80 hours a week and paid more income tax than Facebook.

item.title: U.S. Calls for Release of Uganda’s Opposition Leader
item.description: The police arrested the most popular challenger to the president before the results of a flawed election were announced.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON

item.title: Fiji Declares a State of Natural Disaster After Fierce Cyclone
item.description: The storm, which had gusts up to 202 miles per hour, killed five people and left villages destroyed.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Villages such as Ba were hit hard as Cyclone Winston swept through Fiji.

item.title: Fiji Declares a State of Natural Disaster After Fierce Cyclone
item.description: The storm, which had gusts up to 202 miles per hour, killed five people and left villages destroyed.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Villages such as Ba were hit hard as Cyclone Winston swept through Fiji.

item.title: In Zika Epidemic, a Warning on Climate Change
item.description: In the coming decades, global warming is likely to increase the range and speed the life cycle of the particular mosquitoes carrying viruses like Zika.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:description: Smoke from a brush fire in a deforested part of Brazil’s Amazon basin. The Zika virus, which is an epidemic in Brazil, is transmitted mainly by mosquitoes.

item.title: Afghan Troops Retreat Under Pressure From Taliban
item.description: The pullout in the southern Helmand Province is the latest blow to an area that had been teetering for months in the face of resurgent Taliban members.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Afghans fleeing because of battles between government troops and militants are checked by the police Saturday in Musa Qala.

item.title: Yoweri Museveni, Uganda’s President, Wins a Widely Criticized Election
item.description: Mr. Museveni, the country’s longtime president, cruised to victory in an election marred by irregularities, violent protests and the arrest of his main opponent.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON
item.media:description: President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda arriving for a rally in Kampala on Tuesday. He is entering his third decade in office.

item.title: Russia Pulls Back From Cooperating With U.S. on Afghanistan
item.description: On an old Cold War battlefield where Russia fought a nearly decade-long war against United States-supplied fighters, Moscow has a new strategy: the cold shoulder.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: China Labels Protesters ‘Radical Separatists,’ and They Agree
item.description: Violence in the bustling Mong Kok district was the most startling sign yet of the rise of a confrontational local movement and the unlikely goal of Hong Kong independence.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If history decides we’re culpable for the violence, so be it,” said Edward Leung of the Hong Kong Indigenous group.
